questions.text: A 33-year-old male with attempted poisoning was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state. His pulse was 140/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His ABG showed metabolic acidosis. Urine analysis showed Calcium oxalate crystals. Identify the likely poison?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethylene glycol

 

The presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a key diagnostic sign of ethylene glycol poisoning. Metabolic acidosis and drowsiness is also indicating towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formaldehyde is ruled out because the patient’s symptoms like, metabolic acidosis, and the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, do not align with the typical effects of formaldehyde poisoning, which usually involves respiratory and mucous membrane irritation.

 

Option C. Paraldehyde While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with paraldehyde poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Option D. Methyl alcohol (methanol) While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with methyl alcohol poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of glycol poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning

 

Ethylene glycol is the major constituent of antifreeze solutions. It is a clear, colorless, odorless, non-volatile liquid with a bitter-sweet taste.

 

Action: Ethylene glycol itself is not toxic, but the toxicity is due to metabolites glycolic and oxalic acids which inhibits oxidative phosphorylation.

 

  • Oxalic acid combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals which accumulates in the proximal convoluted tubules causing renal failure.
  • Metabolic acidosis occurs from glycolic acid.
  • Ingestion of ethylene glycol produces CNS depression which may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. Metabolites of ethylene glycol produce severe metabolic acidosis and damage to the brain, heart, and kidneys

 

Treatment - Sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

 

The triad of Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL) points to a diagnosis of Congenital rubella syndrome

 

Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections.

 

Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles)

 

Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option B. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Option C. Congenital cytomegalovirus infection: Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), cataract, and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters is released from SA node in response to increase in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetylcholine

 

Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter released by the parasympathetic nervous system. When blood pressure increases, baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch detect this change and stimulate the parasympathetic nervous system. This leads to the release of acetylcholine from the vagus nerve at the SA node, resulting in a decrease in heart rate (bradycardia) and a reduction in cardiac output, which helps to lower blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter involved in several central nervous system functions, including movement and reward. It is not directly involved in the regulation of heart rate or blood pressure in the context of the SA node.

 

Option C. Epinephrine: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is released by the adrenal medulla and acts on both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors. It generally increases heart rate and blood pressure. It is not released from the SA node in response to increased blood pressure.

 

Option D. Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine is a neurotransmitter released by the sympathetic nervous system. It acts on alpha and beta adrenergic receptors to increase heart rate and blood pressure. However, in response to increased blood pressure, the sympathetic activity is typically reduced, and norepinephrine release is decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the correct neurotransmitter released from the SA node in response to an increase in blood pressure is acetylcholine, as it is part of the parasympathetic response to decrease heart rate and lower blood pressure.

questions.text: Identify the hormone from the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth Hormone

 

The above image shows variations in growth hormone levels through the day.

 

The level is low during the day and is around 5 ng/mL (another reference says <2 ng/mL) increasing in response to specific stimuli like:

 

  1. Exercise.
  2. Physical and emotional stress.
  3. Ingestion of protein.
  4. In hypoglycaemia (Starvation, Fasting)
  5. Spike occurs after 3 hours of meals or exercise.

 

In adults and children in the evening, it shows the highest level.

 

The secretion of GH is episodic and variable; sometimes, the level may reach 40 ng/ml in a healthy subject.

 

The highest values are noted during the deepest sleep level. So, its level is increased during sleep. The GH may increase ten times the normal level during sleep.

 

So, the best time to for growth hormone is 60 to 90 minutes after deep sleep. Or do the exercise for 30 minutes and get the GH sample, which will be at the highest level.

           

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cortisol: Incorrect. Cortisol typically peaks in the early morning and lowers throughout the day, not in response to meals or exercise in this marked pattern.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen levels do not show such acute changes in response to daily activities like meals or exercise.

 

Option D. Insulin: Incorrect. Insulin spikes are typically observed post-meal but would not show the pattern of peaks associated with exercise or sleep as depicted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone levels exhibit significant variability, influenced by factors such as time of day, meals, exercise, and sleep, with the highest levels occurring during deep sleep. This pattern underlines the hormone's critical roles in growth, metabolism, and recovery processes.

questions.text:
Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies? (NEET PG 2022)

 

  1. Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg
  2. Baby on artificial feeds
  3. Baby of working mother/single parent
  4. Baby with weight <85% of expected weight
  5. Birth order of 3 or more
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Among the given options, babies on artificial feeds and babies of working/single parents are considered at-risk babies.

 

 

It is important to identify children at risk and give special intensive care. This is done because these children contribute largely to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infants on artificial feeding or with a working/single parent are at risk and require intensive care to prevent perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia


Lewy body dementia is a progressive and irreversible neurodegenerative disorder.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. B12 deficiency: Reversible with supplementation.
 

Option B. Normal pressure hydrocephalus: Reversible with shunting.
 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Reversible with thyroid hormone replacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy body dementia is not a reversible cause of dementia.

questions.text: A newborn female presents with continuous dribbling of urine. The image below shows the pathology from which the patient is suffering. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is the diagnosis in this case, which is characterized by an open, inside-out bladder on the surface of the lower abdominal wall, and an exposed dorsal urethra. The pathogenesis of this condition is thought to be due to an embryological defect in abdominal wall development. In affected females, there is epispadias with bifid clitoris and small, laterally displaced labia minora, while in affected males, there is epispadias as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrochisis: The abdominal contents will be out and not covered in a sac.

 

 

 

Option C. Superior vesical fissure: A defect of closure in the infra-umbilical abdominal wall through which vesical mucous membrane protruded. A probe introduced into the urethra appeared externally at the place of the infraumbilical defect. Following the diagnosis of superior vesical fissure, resection of the protruding vesical mucous membrane and closure were carried out.

 

Option D. Anterior ectopic anus: The above features and image doesn’t correlate with the mentioned findings in the question.

 

Educational Objective:


Bladder exstrophy presents as an exposed, inside-out bladder on the abdominal wall, often associated with continuous dribbling of urine, especially in female newborns with epispadias and bifid clitoris.

choices.text: Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes
Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts
Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys
Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys

questions.text: PTH increases Calcium in blood. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys:

 

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) primarily acts to increase the concentration of calcium in the blood. It achieves this through several mechanisms:

  1. Stimulation of osteoclasts to resorb bone, leading to the release of calcium from the bones.
  2. Increased absorption of calcium in the intestines.
  3. Stimulation of the kidneys to reabsorb more calcium, reducing its excretion in the urine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes: Osteocytes are embedded in the bone matrix and are not directly involved in the rapid release of calcium. Osteoclasts, on the other hand, are responsible for bone resorption.

 

Option B. Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts: Osteoclasts are indeed involved in the rapid release of calcium from bones. However, the complete action of PTH includes not only osteoclast activity but also increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Option D. Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys: While PTH does stimulate increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, the complete action also involves the rapid release of calcium from bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the role of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in regulating calcium levels in the blood and the mechanisms by which it accomplishes this task.

 

  • Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation: PTH is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located in the neck. Its primary function is to regulate calcium homeostasis in the body, ensuring that blood calcium levels remain within a narrow and critical range.
  • Increase in Blood Calcium: PTH increases blood calcium levels by stimulating various physiological processes:
    • Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream.
    • Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body.
    • Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • Negative Feedback Loop: The regulation of PTH secretion is tightly controlled by a negative feedback loop. When blood calcium levels drop below the normal range, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which acts to raise calcium levels. Once calcium levels return to normal, PTH secretion decreases, preventing excess calcium in the blood.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with 6 months of pain and stiffness in her hands, which is worse in the morning and lasts over an hour. On examination, her hands show swelling and joint deformities, as seen in the image. Laboratory tests show elevated inflammatory markers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Rheumatoid arthritis

 

Explanation:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the small joints, including the hands, wrists, and feet. It typically presents with symmetrical joint pain and swelling, particularly involving the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. A hallmark feature of RA is morning stiffness lasting longer than 1 hour, which improves with activity, in contrast to other conditions like osteoarthritis where stiffness is shorter and worsens with use.

 

The joint deformities seen in RA, as illustrated in the image, occur due to chronic inflammation of the synovium (the lining of the joints), which leads to joint destruction over time. Common deformities include ulnar deviation, swan-neck deformities (hyperextension of the PIP joints with flexion of the DIP joints), and boutonnière deformities (flexion of the PIP joints with hyperextension of the DIP joints).

 

Laboratory findings in RA often show elevated inflammatory markers such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Patients may also test positive for rheumatoid factor (RF) or anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies, which are more specific for RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoarthritis: A degenerative joint disease that mainly affects large, weight-bearing joints like the knees and hips, with shorter morning stiffness and joint pain that worsens with activity.

 

Option B. Gout: An inflammatory arthritis that typically presents with acute monoarticular pain, most commonly in the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint (big toe), not symmetrical polyarthritis.

 

Option D. Psoriatic arthritis: An inflammatory condition associated with psoriasis that affects both skin and joints, but tends to involve asymmetrical joint involvement and dactylitis (sausage digits).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes symmetrical polyarthritis, primarily affecting small joints. Key features include morning stiffness lasting over an hour, joint swelling, and progressive deformities. Early diagnosis and treatment with disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are crucial to prevent long-term joint damage and disability.

questions.text: In a patient with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). All the following can be used for treatment except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptokinase

 

In the management of NSTEMI, the focus is on antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy rather than fibrinolytic agents like streptokinase. Streptokinase is specifically used in the treatment of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) where there is a fibrin-rich thrombus completely occluding a coronary artery. NSTEMI, in contrast, involves a partial occlusion by a platelet-rich thrombus, and fibrinolytics are generally not recommended because they are less effective and could potentially increase the risk of bleeding without significant benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: As a foundational antiplatelet agent, aspirin is used in both STEMI and NSTEMI to reduce platelet aggregation and further thrombus formation.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel: This is another antiplatelet drug that is used in the management of both STEMI and NSTEMI as part of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) along with aspirin to provide greater protection against thrombotic events.

 

Option D. Prasugrel: Similar to clopidogrel, prasugrel is used in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) management, including NSTEMI, especially when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is planned, due to its potent antiplatelet effects. (Prasugrel is given peri-procedurally).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21e chap 118/3518

questions.text: The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chorioretinitis

 

  • The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis.
  • Congenital toxoplasmosis is an infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii that occurs when a pregnant woman becomes infected and passes the infection on to her developing fetus. The severity of the infection can vary depending on the timing of the infection during pregnancy and the degree of immune response mounted by the fetus.
  • It is acquired perorally from ingesting food that contains oocysts; transplacentally, during vaginal delivery; or rarely, parenterally.
  • Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, occurring in up to 80% of affected infants. It is a type of eye inflammation that affects the retina and can lead to vision impairment or blindness if left untreated.
  • Other common manifestations of congenital toxoplasmosis include hydrocephalus (accumulation of fluid in the brain), hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), but these are less common than chorioretinitis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrocephalus: Accumulation of fluid in the brain can occur in congenital toxoplasmosis but is less common than chorioretinitis.

 

Option C. Hepatosplenomegaly: Enlargement of the liver and spleen is another possible manifestation but not as common as chorioretinitis.

 

Option D. Thrombocytopenia: Low platelet count can occur but is less common compared to chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, affecting up to 80% of infected infants and potentially leading to vision impairment or blindness.

questions.text: Handedness is seen at the age of? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 years

 

At age of 3 years, handedness is seen. The child may become frustrated if attempts are made in changing the hand preference.

 

Other milestones reached at 3 years-

 

  • Rides tricycle
  • Alternate feet going upstairs
  • Builds a tower of 9 blocks
  • Copies a circle
  • Knows full name and gender

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: Standing without support comes by 1 year

 

Option B. 2 years: A child has vocab of 100 words by 2 years

 

Option D. 4 years: A child can tell poem & stories by 4 years

 

Educational Objective:

 

At the age of 3 years, handedness is seen.

choices.text: Great saphenous vein

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the upper arm. Imaging reveals a significant tear in the brachial artery. The vascular surgeon plans to repair the damaged artery using a graft from another part of the patient's body. Which of the following is the most appropriate graft source for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Great saphenous vein

 

Explanation:

 

The great saphenous vein is commonly used as a graft in vascular surgeries due to its accessibility, length, and suitability for arterial repair. In cases of brachial artery injury caused by trauma, such as a stab wound, repairing the artery with a vein graft allows for a tension-free anastomosis, which is essential for restoring proper blood flow. The great saphenous vein is typically harvested from the patient's leg (usually the uninjured leg) and is used to bypass or replace the damaged section of the brachial artery. This method is particularly effective when the artery has a significant tear or cannot be repaired by direct suturing alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Radial artery: Although the radial artery can sometimes be used as a graft, it is less commonly harvested for such purposes due to its important role in maintaining blood supply to the hand.

 

Option C) Femoral artery: The femoral artery is rarely used as a graft source because it is a major artery supplying the lower limb and its removal could lead to significant complications.

 

Option D) Subclavian vein: The subclavian vein is not typically used for grafting, as it plays a crucial role in venous return from the upper limb and would not be as suitable as the great saphenous vein for arterial repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For vascular repair, such as in cases of brachial artery injury, the great saphenous vein is often the preferred graft source due to its availability, ease of harvesting, and adaptability for arterial reconstruction. Using a vein graft allows for a tension-free repair and restoration of proper blood flow.

choices.text: Ventricular dysrhythmias are common in children
The no flow phase precedes the period of cardiac arrest in children.
More ventilation to be given compared to chest compressions in children
Dysrhythmias are most often due to respiratory insufficiency in children

questions.text: True regarding the difference between adult and pediatric resuscitation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dysrhythmias are most often due to respiratory insufficiency in children

 

In pediatric patients, dysrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms) are more likely to be caused by respiratory insufficiency or hypoxia rather than intrinsic cardiac issues, which are more common causes of dysrhythmias in adults. Hypoxia and respiratory failure are the leading causes of cardiac arrest in children, as their cardiovascular systems are generally healthy compared to adults, where coronary artery disease is more prevalent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular dysrhythmias are common in children: Ventricular dysrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation, are relatively uncommon in children. In pediatric patients, the most common dysrhythmias requiring treatment are supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and bradycardia, often secondary to hypoxia or other respiratory issues.

 

Option B. The no-flow phase precedes the period of cardiac arrest in children: The no-flow phase refers to the period between the onset of cardiac arrest and the initiation of effective CPR. While this phase occurs in both adults and children, it does not specifically precede cardiac arrest. The phases of cardiac arrest include the pre-arrest phase, the no-flow phase, the low-flow phase (which begins with CPR), and the post-resuscitation phase (which begins with the return of spontaneous circulation).

 

Option C. More ventilation to be given compared to chest compressions in children: The correct chest compression to ventilation ratio in pediatric CPR is either 30:2 or 15:2, depending on whether one or two rescuers are present. Providing excessive ventilation can decrease venous return, reduce coronary and cerebral blood flow, lower cardiac output, and ultimately decrease the chances of return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). Therefore, the emphasis is on high-quality chest compressions with appropriate ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pediatric resuscitation, dysrhythmias are most commonly due to respiratory insufficiency or hypoxia, unlike in adults, where intrinsic cardiac causes are more prevalent.

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liver iron concentration

 

  • Children with thalassemia who undergo multiple blood transfusions are at risk of iron overload, which can cause significant damage to organs such as the liver, heart, and endocrine glands.
  • Monitoring liver iron concentration is the best method to assess iron overload in such children, as it is an indicator of total body iron stores.
  • Liver iron concentration can be measured invasively using a liver biopsy or non-invasively using T2 MRI of the liver. The latter is preferred due to its non-invasiveness.
  • Treatment for iron overload in thalassemia patients typically involves the use of chelation therapy, which helps to remove excess iron from the body. Deferoxamine is typically given through intravenous or subcutaneous infusion, while deferasirox and deferiprone can be given orally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI T2 myocardium: Quantitative iron overload in the heart is determined using a T2 MRI of the myocardium. However, it can be done sooner if there are symptoms of severe iron overload. It is often performed in children older than 10 years. If the patient's transfusion and chelation histories are unknown, it can still be done.

 

Option C. Serum ferritin: Although serum ferritin is elevated, other inflammatory disorders also cause it to be elevated, making it a less sensitive marker.

 

Option D. NTBI (Non-transferrin-bound iron): Iron in plasma is typically bound to cccc. However, when there is an excess of iron, it is unable to bind to transferrin, which results in the formation of non-transferrin-bound iron. (NTBI). It may serve as a marker for iron excess, however albumin, citrate, and uric acid in the plasma all have an impact. As a result, it cannot be utilized as a tool to quantify iron overload and serve as a guide for designing chelation therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method to detect iron overload in a patient receiving repeated blood transfusions is Liver iron concentration.

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

 

The most appropriate next step for a child with a VP shunt who presents with symptoms suspicious for meningitis is to obtain blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples from the shunt tap and/or lumbar puncture. It is important to diagnose and treat meningitis quickly in patients with VP shunts, as untreated meningitis can cause shunt malfunction and other complications.

 

The diagnosis of meningitis in a child with a VP shunt requires obtaining blood cultures and CSF samples. Blood cultures are needed to identify the causative organism, while CSF samples are used to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the infection. CSF can be obtained either through a shunt tap or a lumbar puncture, depending on the child's clinical status and the availability of the appropriate resources.

 

VP shunt fluid is usually obtained from a reservoir that is easily accessible subcutaneously. After sterile preparation, the reservoir should be punctured with a 25-gauge needle. The risk of introducing infection is also low (4.1%).

 

 

Ventriculoperitoneal shunt:

 

 

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CS) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

 

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following:

 

  • Infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, usually from Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Shunt over drainage (slit ventricles)
  • Shunt nephritis
  • Shunt disconnection
  • Shunt obstruction
  • Inguinal hernia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch: as the patient is showing features of complication, wait and watch will not be the appropriate answer.

 

Option B. Check shunt patency by nuclear study: we should check the patency of the shunt but as the patient is showing signs of meningitis we should do a CSF analysis by shunt tap.

 

Option C. Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture: the main source of infection is from the shunt, so taking CSF sample from there is best.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abnormal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

 

This abnormal posturing is caused by tetanospasmin which is produced by clostridium tetani. It inhibits presynaptic GABA and glycine release.

 

 

Clostridium tetani is an obligate anaerobic, gram-positive bacillus with terminal round spore (drumstick appearance).

 

Tetanus is manifested by skeletal muscle spasms and autonomic nervous system disturbance. Tetanus only affects skeletal muscle, smooth muscle, and cardiac muscle function normally.

 

C. tetani produces two exotoxins–tetanolysin and tetanospasmin.

 

  1. Tetanolysin is a heat-labile, oxygen-labile hemolysin antigenically related to the oxygen-labile hemolysins produced by C. perfringens, S. pyogenes, and S. pneumoniae. Tetanolysin damages otherwise viable tissue surrounding the infection and optimizes the conditions for bacterial multiplication.
  2. Tetanospasmin (or tetanus toxin) is a heat-labile, oxygen-stable, plasmid-coded neurotoxin responsible for disease manifestations. Tetanus neurotoxin is released upon cell lysis after bacterial growth under anaerobic conditions (e.g., in deep puncture wounds). It is antigenic and is specifically neutralized by its antitoxin. Its toxoid form is used for vaccine preparation.

 

Mechanism of Tetanus Toxin-

 

Tetanus toxin binds to polysialogangliosides receptors present on motor nerve terminals which results in toxin internalization.

 

Following internalization, tetanus toxin gets transported in a retrograde way from the peripheral nervous system to the central nervous system by retrograde axonal transport. When tetanus toxin reaches inhibitory neuron terminals, it prevents the presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).

 

Incubation period of tetanus is about 6-10 days.

 

 

Clinical features - Patients have prolonged muscle spasms of both flexor and extensor muscles. Patients with tetanus have spastic muscle contractions, difficulty opening the jaw (called lockjaw, “trismus”), a characteristic smile called “risus sardonicus” and contractions of back muscles resulting in backward arching (Opisthotonos position). Patients are extremely irritable, and tetanic seizures develop, brought about by violent, painful muscle contractions following some minor stimulus, such as noise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presynaptic inhibition of Ach receptors: This mechanism is not involved in the action of tetanospasmin. It is more relevant to the action of botulinum toxin.

 

Option C. Postsynaptic inhibition of GABA: This is not the mechanism of action for tetanospasmin. Tetanospasmin acts presynaptically.

 

Option D. Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release: This describes the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin, not tetanospasmin. Botulinum toxin cleaves SNARE proteins, which prevents the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to flaccid paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanospasmin, the toxin responsible for tetanus, acts by inhibiting the presynaptic release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contraction and the characteristic symptoms of tetanus, such as muscle spasms and opisthotonos.

questions.text: What type of tinea is likely affecting the 10-year-old child who presents with patchy hair loss as shown in the image below, along with the presence of black dots in the areas of hair loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothrix

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of endothrix type of tinea capitis.

 

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton associated Tinea capitis - Terbinafine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of patchy hair loss with black dots in the areas of hair loss in a child is indicative of an endothrix type of tinea capitis, where the fungal spores are located inside the hair shaft, causing it to break at the scalp level.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.8, 32.38-32.40

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kallman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Kallman syndrome is a condition of hypothalamic hypogonadism that presents as primary amenorrhea with anosmia. It does not cause secondary amenorrhea.

 

Causes of secondary amenorrhea:

 

  • Sheehan's syndrome: This is a condition where the pituitary gland is damaged due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Asherman's syndrome: This condition involves the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity, often as a result of surgical procedures like dilation and curettage (D&C), leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Turner mosaic: This refers to a form of Turner syndrome where some of the cells have the typical 45,X karyotype and others have a different karyotype (e.g., 46,XX). It can lead to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Premature ovarian failure: This condition occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40, causing secondary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner's mosaic: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to ovarian insufficiency.

 

Option C. Sheehan's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to pituitary damage.

 

Option D. Asherman's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to uterine scarring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kallman syndrome is a cause of primary amenorrhea due to hypothalamic hypogonadism and anosmia. Secondary amenorrhea can be caused by conditions such as Sheehan's syndrome, Asherman's syndrome, Turner mosaic, and premature ovarian failure.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg375

choices.text: Virus shedding is present before symptoms begins
5-12 years is a high-risk group

questions.text: Which of the following is false about influenza? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5-12 years is a high-risk group

 

People at greater risk of severe disease or complications when infected are:

 

  1. pregnant women
  2. Children under 59 months
  3. Elderly
  4. Individuals with chronic medical conditions (such as chronic cardiac, pulmonary, renal, metabolic, neurodevelopmental, liver or hematologic diseases)
  5. Individuals with immunosuppressive conditions (such as HIV/AIDS, receiving chemotherapy or steroids, or malignancy).
  6. Health care workers are at high risk acquiring influenza virus infection due to increased exposure to the patients and risk further spread particularly to vulnerable individuals.

 

Mode of transmission – droplet infection

 

Incubation period – 1 to 4 days

 

Contagious period - About one day before developing any symptoms and up to seven days after the symptoms resolve.

 

Birds, especially aquatic birds act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza or bird flu refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR), defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (i.e., household or close contacts), can provide an indication of how social interactions relate to transmission risk. It is 5- 15% for influenza.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Virus shedding is present before symptoms begin: This is true. Influenza can be contagious before symptoms appear, which contributes to its rapid spread.

 

Option C. Aquatic birds act as a reservoir: This is true. Birds, especially aquatic birds, act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza, or bird flu, refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

Option D. Secondary attack rate is 5-15%: This is true. The secondary attack rate (SAR) for influenza, defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (e.g., household or close contacts), is typically between 5-15%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children under 5 years, pregnant women, the elderly, individuals with chronic medical conditions or immunosuppressive conditions, and health care workers are at greater risk of severe disease or complications from influenza. The 5-12 years age group is not specifically categorized as high-risk for severe disease from influenza.

choices.text: Urine leakage during intercourse

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman reports with symptoms of lower urinary tract infection. She denies any pain or blood in the urine. Which of the following is not typically considered a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS)?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Urine leakage during intercourse

 

Explanation:

 

Urine leakage during intercourse (also known as coital incontinence) is not typically classified as a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS). LUTS includes storage symptoms (e.g., frequency, urgency), voiding symptoms (e.g., weak stream, straining), and post-micturitional symptoms (e.g., incomplete bladder emptying). Although coital incontinence may occur in individuals with pelvic floor issues or urinary incontinence, it is not usually categorized as part of LUTS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Frequent urination: A storage symptom of LUTS, where the patient feels the need to urinate more frequently than normal.

 

Option B) Urgency: A storage symptom that involves a sudden, strong urge to urinate, which is difficult to delay.

 

Option C) Post-micturitional incomplete emptying: A post-micturitional symptom where the patient feels their bladder is not fully emptied after voiding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) include storage, voiding, and post-micturitional symptoms. Urine leakage during intercourse is not typically part of LUTS and may indicate pelvic floor or incontinence issues.

questions.text: All of the following nerves are involved in the movement of the eyeball except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The nerve marked as 'A' is the optic nerve (II CN), and is not involved in the movement of the eyeball.

 

The optic nerve is primarily responsible for carrying visual information from the retina to the brain. It is not directly involved in controlling eye movements, but it is crucial for vision itself.

 

The nerves marked in the image are:

 

  • A- Optic nerve (II CN)
  • B- Oculomotor nerve (III CN)
  • C- Abducens nerve (VI CN)
  • D- Trochlear nerve (IV CN)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve (III CN): The oculomotor nerve controls the majority of the eye's movements. It innervates several extraocular muscles responsible for moving the eye in various directions, including upward, downward, and medially. It also controls the pupil's constriction and the accommodation of the lens for focusing on near objects. It innervates all extraocular muscles except - lateral rectus and superior oblique.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve (VI CN): The abducens nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye outward or laterally. It allows for abduction of the eye, helping to look away from the nose.

 

Option D. Trochlear nerve (IV CN): The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for depressing the eye and intorsion (rotation inward). It helps in downward and inward eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliverdin 

 

Meconium is a dark and sticky substance that is normally present in a newborn's intestine at birth and is excreted in the feces after birth. It is first detected in the ileum at around 70-85 days of fetal life and fills the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of meconium is due to bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract, mainly biliverdin, which is formed from the oxidation of bilirubin.

 

  • Biliverdin is responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in newborns. Biliverdin production starts later in gestation or closer to delivery, perhaps due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system.
  • Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.
  • Meconium itself is the first stool of the baby, which contains biliverdin, giving it the greenish-black color.
  • Gut flora: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Option C. Meconium: Meconium is the substance itself, not the cause of its greenish-black color. The color is due to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Gut flora of neonate: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ancylostoma duodenale

 

The egg in the given picture is that of a hookworm. Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus (new world hookworm) are identical.

 

The eggs of hookworm are:

 

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless
  • Not bile stained
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

 

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are round to oval, thick-shelled, and often bile-stained. They have a rough, mammillated outer layer.

 

Option B. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis eggs are usually not seen in stool samples because they hatch within the intestine. The diagnostic stage is the rhabditiform larva found in the stool.

 

Option C. Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm): Enterobius vermicularis eggs are oval, flattened on one side, and have a thick, colorless shell. They are typically detected using the "Scotch tape" method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hookworm eggs are oval, colorless, thin-shelled, and contain 4 to 8 blastomeres. These eggs are not bile-stained and have a clear space between the ovum and the eggshell.

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling below the left earlobe and is experiencing pain. What is the most likely cause of this pain? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Greater auricular nerve

 

The greater auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that supplies the skin of the external ear, the area over the parotid gland, and the angle of the mandible. It is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically arising from the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3. Any acute inflammation of the gland such as acute sialadenitis results in pain in the preauricular region. The pain is mainly due to stretching of the capsule resulting in stimulation of the greater auricular nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) traverses through the parotid gland but does not innervate it. Instead, it provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression. Damage to the facial nerve may lead to facial paralysis or weakness, but it's not directly responsible for sensation or pain below the earlobe.

 

Option B. Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: This is a layer of connective tissue that envelops the neck and extends into the face. It surrounds several structures, including the parotid gland. While the fascia itself isn't directly responsible for sensation, inflammation or infections that cause stretching of this fascia might contribute to discomfort.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal nerve: This is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin above the parotid gland, the external ear, and the external auditory canal. Though it provides sensation to the aforementioned areas, the region described in the scenario (below the earlobe) is not primarily innervated by the auriculotemporal nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Greater auricular nerve originates from the cervical plexus, specifically from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves. It ascends to the parotid gland and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the earlobe, and the area behind the ear, so the greater auricular nerve is most directly responsible for transmitting pain sensations from these regions.

choices.text: Intact cell organelle
Altered cell shape
Enzyme mediated degradation
Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered cell shape

 

Necrosis and apoptosis are two distinct types of cell death, each with its own characteristics.

 

Altered cell shape: While cell shape can change in both necrosis and apoptosis, it is not a reliable indicator to differentiate between the two. The more useful parameter is cell size: in necrosis, cells swell, whereas in apoptosis, cells shrink. Therefore, altered cell shape is not particularly helpful in distinguishing necrosis from apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intact cell organelle: During apoptosis, cell organelles remain intact until the late stages when apoptotic bodies form. These bodies contain tightly packed cytoplasmic components and organelles. In contrast, necrosis is characterized by the breakdown and disintegration of organelles. Thus, the presence of intact organelles helps differentiate apoptosis from necrosis.

 

Option C. Enzyme mediated degradation: This is a hallmark of necrosis. In necrosis, enzymes digest cellular components, leading to the breakdown of organelles and other structures. This feature is not seen in apoptosis, where cellular components are typically preserved until the cell is packaged into apoptotic bodies.

 

Option D. Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change: Necrosis involves the disintegration of organelles and changes in lipids, leading to the loss of cell membrane integrity. This is not a feature of apoptosis, where the membrane remains intact until late stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.

questions.text: Under which of the following, Rhinosporidium seeberi is classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aquatic Protistan protozoa

 

RHINOSPORIDIOSIS

 

  • Causative organism: Rhinosporidium Seeberi (earlier considered fungus, now classified under protozoa)
  • Life cycle: 3 stages: Trophic, Sporangium formation, Endospore production.
  • Spread by contaminated water of ponds, seen commonly in coastal areas
  • Appearance: leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple (strawberry), bleeds on touch.
  • Complaints: Blood tinged nasal discharge & stuffiness
  • Diagnosis by biopsy (spores bursting through chitinous wall of sporangia)
  • Treatment: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Although previously considered a fungus, current classifications based on molecular analysis place Rhinosporidium seeberi under protozoa.

 

Option B: Viruses are infectious agents that replicate inside the living cells of organisms which is not a characteristic of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Option D: Bacteria are single-celled microorganisms with simple internal structures, quite distinct from the complex life cycle and morphology of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidium seeberi, responsible for rhinosporidiosis, is classified as an aquatic Protistan protozoa, not a fungus, highlighting the importance of accurate organism classification in understanding transmission and management of infections.

questions.text: A female presented with excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory for one year. On examination the BMI was 43 kg/m² and BP was 170/98 mmHg. ABG was done in awake state and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? PaO2: 70 mmHg PaCO2: 53 mmHg HCO3: 33 mmHg. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), also known as Pickwickian syndrome, is characterized by obesity (BMI >30 kg/m²), hypoventilation (PaCO2 >45 mmHg), and lack of significant underlying lung disease. The ABG findings showing hypercapnia (high PaCO2) and hypoxemia (low PaO2) in the awake state are indicative of OHS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructive sleep apnea: Occurs during sleep, not necessarily presenting with hypercapnia in the awake state.
 

Option C. Central sleep apnea: Characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep without the obesity-related hypoventilation.
 

Option D. Narcolepsy: Does not typically present with ABG abnormalities or obesity hypoventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome involves obesity, chronic hypercapnia, and hypoxemia, primarily in the awake state.

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

Autoimmunity refers to immune reactions against self-antigens. Normal persons are unresponsive (tolerant) to their own (self) antigens, and autoimmunity results from a failure of self-tolerance.

 

Self-tolerance involves two broad mechanisms: Central Tolerance and Peripheral Tolerance.

 

AIRE (Autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some peripheral tissue-restricted self-antigens in the thymus and is critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these self-antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: NOTCH1 plays a role in cell growth and division (proliferation), maturation (differentiation), and self-destruction (apoptosis).

 

Option B. E2A: E2A proteins function by recruiting proteins that drive epigenetic remodeling that precedes transcription.

 

Option C. Rag ½: Recombination-activating genes RAG 1 and RAG 2 initiate the molecular processes that lead to lymphocyte receptor formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene is crucial for promoting self-tolerance by ensuring that developing T cells in the thymus are exposed to self-antigens, thus preventing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-wine stain on her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows a leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glaucoma

 

Glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a rare congenital vascular disorder characterized by facial capillary malformation (port-wine stain) and associated capillary-venous malformations affecting the brain and eye.

 

Mechanisms of glaucoma. The two main theories regarding the mechanism of glaucoma in eyes with SWS are developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle and elevated episcleral venous pressure, each of which leads to aqueous outflow restriction leading to rise in IOP. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: This is inflammation of the uvea and not a typical manifestation of SWS.

 

Option B. Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a group of genetic disorders that affect the retina's ability to respond to light, not commonly associated with SWS.

 

Option C. Keratitis: Inflammation or infection of the cornea, not linked to SWS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome, particularly those presenting with facial port-wine stains and neurological symptoms, glaucoma is a critical ocular manifestation to consider. Regular ophthalmic evaluations are essential due to the high incidence of glaucoma in these patients, focusing on managing elevated IOP to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: Efferent to which nucleus of thalamus from indicated structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

 

 

The image shows a coronal section of the brain with the indicated structure being the fornix. The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as a major output tract of the hippocampus. It is involved in the Papez circuit, which plays a key role in the control of memory functions.

 

  • Anterior Nucleus of the Thalamus: The fornix carries signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is an integral part of the Papez circuit, involved in emotional and memory processing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral: The lateral nuclei of the thalamus are involved in sensory relay and integration but are not the primary efferent targets of the fornix.

 

Option C. Ventro-postero-lateral: This nucleus is involved in the relay of sensory information from the body to the brain but is not connected to the fornix.

 

Option D. Pulvinar: The pulvinar nucleus is involved in visual processing and attention, not directly associated with the fornix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix transmits signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, playing a crucial role in memory processing within the Papez circuit.

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of the carotid sheath except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sympathetic chain

 

Explanation:

 

The carotid sheath's content is not the sympathetic chain. It is located in the neck, behind the carotid sheath and in front of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae.

 

The carotid sheath is a layer of loose connective tissue formed by adjacent portions of the investing layer of deep cervical fascia, the pretracheal fascia, and the prevertebral fascia.

 

Contents of carotid sheath:

 

  • Common and internal carotid arteries
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve (10th Cranial nerve)
  • Ansa cervicalis

 

Note: The glossopharyngeal, accessory, and hypoglossal nerves are located in the carotid sheath's upper portion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carotid artery: The common carotid artery and its internal branch (the internal carotid artery) are primary contents of the carotid sheath. In the neck, the common carotid bifurcates into the internal and external carotid arteries. Only the internal carotid artery continues to ascend within the carotid sheath.

 

Option C. Internal jugular vein: The internal jugular vein is a major vein in the neck that drains the brain, face, and much of the neck. It runs in close proximity to the internal and common carotid arteries and is another primary content of the carotid sheath.

 

Option D. 10th cranial nerve, which is also known as Vagus nerve. It is present in carotid sheath medial to internal jugular vein and lateral to internal carotid artery. It is a mixed nerve.It descends from the skull base through the jugular foramen and is present in the carotid sheath. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sympathetic chain (sympathetic trunk) is a bilateral series of ganglia that run vertically alongside the vertebral column. It is involved in the autonomic sympathetic innervation of the body. Importantly, the sympathetic chain itself is not contained within the carotid sheath. However, sympathetic fibers that come from the chain (e.g., the carotid plexus) do accompany structures within the sheath, especially the internal and common carotid arteries.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain and is diagnosed with intussusception. During surgical intervention, multiple polyps are discovered throughout his gastrointestinal tract. A resected segment of the bowel is sent for histopathological analysis, and the findings are shown in the image below. Considering the clinical scenario and histopathological features, what is the most likely type of polyp?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Hamartomatous polyp

 

Explanation:

 

A hamartomatous polyp is characterized by disorganized but normal tissue elements from the GI tract, which are often found in conditions like Peutz-Jeghers syndrome or juvenile polyposis syndrome. These polyps are benign and do not have a significant risk of malignant transformation but may cause complications like intussusception due to their size or location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Adenomatous polyp: Adenomatous polyps are premalignant and have a risk of transforming into colorectal cancer, often showing dysplasia, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option C) Hyperplastic polyp: Hyperplastic polyps are benign and typically occur in the distal colon without causing significant symptoms like abdominal pain or bleeding.

 

Option D) Inflammatory polyp: Inflammatory polyps are usually associated with inflammatory bowel diseases and present in patients with chronic GI inflammation, which is not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hamartomatous polyps are benign growths made up of disorganized but normal tissue. They are commonly seen in children and adolescents, particularly in syndromes like Peutz-Jeghers and juvenile polyposis, and may lead to complications such as intussusception.

choices.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period
A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
A person who acquired pathogen from patient
A patient who became a carrier

questions.text: The term "paradoxical carrier" is defined as: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier

 

A paradoxical carrier is defined as a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, yet does not exhibit any signs or symptoms of the disease. This situation is paradoxical because the pathogen is typically transmitted directly from an infected patient to a new host, but in this case, it has been passed from one asymptomatic carrier to another. This type of carrier plays a significant role in the epidemiology of certain infectious diseases by perpetuating the transmission cycle without showing clinical symptoms themselves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period:  This describes an incubatory carrier, who sheds infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. This is different from a paradoxical carrier, as it involves shedding pathogens before symptoms appear.

 

Option C. A person who acquired pathogen from patient:  This does not describe a paradoxical carrier. It refers to a typical transmission scenario where a pathogen is acquired directly from an infected patient, rather than another asymptomatic carrier.

 

Option D. A patient who became a carrier:  This refers to a convalescent carrier or a chronic carrier. A convalescent carrier is someone who continues to shed the disease agent during the recovery period, while a chronic carrier harbors the pathogen long-term. Neither term is synonymous with a paradoxical carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A paradoxical carrier is a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, but who does not show any signs or symptoms of the disease.
  • Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease.
  • Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence.
  • Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.

questions.text: A microbiologist stained a tissue sample and found thin, filamentous bacteria, which resembled Nocardia sp. What other staining technique should be done to confirm the presence of Nocardia? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Modified acid-fast stain

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (mZN stain) is a type of differential bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria. Acid fast organisms are those which are capable of retaining the primary stain when treated with an acid (fast=holding capacity). Members of the Actinomycetes, genus Nocardia (N. brasiliensis and N. asteroides are opportunistic pathogens) are partially acid-fast. Oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora, are also acid-fast. Hence they can also be detected and identified through mZN staining procedure

 

The reagents used for modified Ziehl–Neelsen staining are absolute methanol (for fixation), kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin (primary stain), acid alcohol (for decolorization), and methylene blue (counter stain). Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents. Kinyoun’s carbol fuschin has greater concentration of phenol and basic fuschin and does not require heating to stain properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ziehl-Neelsen staining is not specific for Nocardia as it is primarily used for Mycobacteria which require heating of the stain.

 

Option B: Silver impregnation is used for fungi and certain bacteria like Legionella, but not typically for Nocardia.

 

Option C: Albert stain is used for staining metachromatic granules in Corynebacteria, not for Nocardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The modified acid-fast stain should be used to confirm the presence of Nocardia due to its weak acid-fast nature and characteristic "beaded" appearance.

questions.text: What does the given image represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypnogram

 

Image is showing a graphical representation of the stages of sleep over time, which is seen in Hypnogram.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electroencephalogram (EEG): A graphical representation of electrical activity in the brain. The tracing typically displays waveforms such as alpha, beta, delta, and theta waves.

 

Option C. Polysomnogram: A comprehensive recording used during a sleep study that includes an EEG (brain activity), as well as eye movements, muscle activity, heart rate, respiratory effort, air flow, and blood oxygen levels.

 

Option D. Epworth Sleep Assessment: It's not a graph or image; it's a questionnaire used to determine the level of daytime sleepiness.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hypnogram is a graphical representation of the stages of sleep over time, usually throughout a night.

 

Reference: Textbook of Psychiatry by Allan Tasman, 4th edition, Page No 1271.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the tape shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

 

  1. It is called Shelter's tape.
  2. It is used to assess severe acute malnutrition.
  3. Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm is considered undernourished.
  4. It is useful mainly for frontline field workers.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

The tape shown in the image is known as Shakir's tape (not Shelter's tape). It is a tool primarily used to assess Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children aged 6-59 months by measuring the Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM): Shakir's tape is specifically designed to measure the MUAC, which is an important indicator of malnutrition. MUAC is a quick and reliable method for assessing malnutrition, especially in resource-limited settings.
  • MUAC Readings and Color Coding:
    • Red: Less than 11.5 cm, indicating severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
    • Yellow: 11.5 to 12.5 cm, indicating moderate malnutrition or risk of malnutrition.
    • Green: Greater than 12.5 cm, indicating a normal nutritional status.
  • Frontline Field Workers: The tape is especially useful for frontline field workers who are often responsible for screening large numbers of children in community settings. It is simple to use, does not require advanced training, and can quickly identify children who need nutritional intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 1 (Shelter's tape): This is incorrect; the tape is correctly called Shakir's tape.

 

Option 3 (Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm): This range is not considered undernourished according to the color coding system used in Shakir's tape. A reading below 11.5 cm is considered severe acute malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shakir's tape is a tool used to assess severe acute malnutrition by measuring the mid-upper arm circumference, particularly useful for frontline field workers in resource-limited settings.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism. What would be the appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Spherical equivalent spectacles

 

The appropriate management for myopic astigmatism in a 15-year-old girl (<18 years) would be spherical equivalent spectacles.

 

The three components of prescription in astigmatism are:

 

  • Power of the spherical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre sphere (DS)
  • Power of the cylindrical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre cylinder (DC)
  • Axis or orientation of the cylinder.

 

The cylindrical power and axis are correcting the astigmatic part of the refractive error. If an astigmatic eye were to be corrected with a spherical lens alone, the result would be a blur circle on the retina, called the circle of least confusion.

 

The spherical lens power places the circle of least confusion on the retina and is called the spherical equivalent. It is defined as the spherical power whose focal point coincides with the circle of least confusion, where one would see minimal blurring in their vision.
 

 

For example, for spherical power is +2 and cylindrical power is +3,

Spherical equivalent = +2.00 +(+3.00 /2) = +3.50.

 

Spherical equivalent spectacles are given if one has to give less cylinder power than was measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. and C - LASIK and Femto LASIK: should be done in patients above 18 years of age.

 

Option D. Implantable Collamer lens: is indicated for patients 21-45 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical interventions like LASIK and Femto LASIK are not recommended for individuals under 18 years of age.

choices.text: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.text: A 45-year-old male worker presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, irritability, fatigue, and memory problems. He works in a battery manufacturing factory for the last 20 years. On further investigations, he is diagnosed with lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption contributing to his condition in such industrial environments? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inhaled lead dust

 

  • In industrial environments such as battery manufacturing factories, the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption is through inhalation of lead dust.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead Poisoning is known as ‘Plumbism’, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic

 

  • Greatest source of lead in Lead Poisoning (Plumbism, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic) is Gasoline/petrol/vehicular exhaust/automobile exhaust
  • Mode of absorption: Lead can be absorbed by inhalation (most common mode), ingestion or through skin

 

Additional Information

 

Clinical picture of lead poisoning:

 

  • Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign
  • Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic
  • Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs
  • Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
  • Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea)
  • Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop
  • Lead encephalopathy
  • CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds

 

Diagnosis of lead poisoning:

 

 

A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU).

 

Treatment: EDTA

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Glucose

 

Rheumatoid pleural effusion, associated with rheumatoid arthritis, typically presents with low glucose levels, making high glucose the correct answer as it is not a characteristic found in such effusions. The low glucose in rheumatoid pleural effusion is due to increased metabolic activity of leukocytes and pleural cells which consume glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RA factor: The presence of RA factor (Rheumatoid factor) in pleural fluid is commonly seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid factor is an autoantibody found in the blood of approximately 80% of adults with rheumatoid arthritis. Its presence in pleural fluid reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of the disease.

 

Option B. Cholesterol crystals: Cholesterol crystals in the pleural fluid are indicative of a long-standing effusion, which can occur in chronic rheumatoid pleuritis. These crystals form as the pleural fluid becomes more concentrated over time due to the chronic nature of the inflammation.

 

Option D. High LDH: High levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in the pleural fluid are a common feature of exudative effusions, including those caused by rheumatoid arthritis. LDH is an enzyme present in most cells and is released into the pleural fluid when cells are damaged or destroyed, reflecting the inflammatory processes occurring in rheumatoid pleuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient came to hospital who has not eaten anything for 2 days. Which of the following tests will be positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 3

 

Explanation:

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3

 

Rothera's test: Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulphate. Add a few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine. Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.

 

Other tests

 

Test 1: Benedict’s test: To 5 mL Benedict’s reagent, add 0.5 mL urine. Boil for 2 minutes. Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars. Black colour (muddy brown) is seen if homogentisic acid is present. Disaccharides may be identified by alkali destruction test. As there is low glucose in blood and will not be excreted in urine. So It will be negative.

 

The urine of a patient with diabetic keto acidosis will give positive Benedict's test as well as Rothera's test. But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.

 

Test 2: Shows the heat coagulation test. The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. Since proteins are generally conserved during fasting to protect muscle mass, this test will be negative, rather proteins will be conserved to protect muscles.

 

Educational Objective

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketosis, which can be detected by Rothera’s test (test 3), resulting in a positive result for ketone bodies in the urine.

choices.text: Both A and R are correct and R is correct explanation of A
Both A and R are correct and R is not correct explanation of A
A is true and R is false
A is false and R is true

questions.text:
Assertion: In a patient admitted in hospital for community acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta lactams and azithromycin is given.

 

Reason: The combination covers gram positive organisms as well as anaerobes.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A is true and R is false

 

  • In patients admitted in hospital for community acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta lactams and azithromycin is given. Beta lactams covers the gram positive and gram negative organisms whereas azithromycin covers the atypical mycobacteria like mycoplasma and chlamydia.
  • Alternative to this therapy is fluoroquinolones.
  • If a patient is not admitted, then either beta lactams alone or macrolides is prescribed.

 

Educational objective:

 

In hospitalized patients with community-acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta-lactams and azithromycin is used to cover typical and atypical bacterial pathogens, not anaerobes.

 

Reference: Katzung 13th/878

questions.text: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ectopic ureter

 

The clinical presentation described is most consistent with an ectopic ureter. An ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly where the ureter does not insert into the bladder at the normal location (the trigone). Instead, it may insert outside the bladder, such as into the urethra, vagina, or other structures in females. This abnormal insertion leads to continuous dribbling of urine because the urine bypasses the bladder's normal storage function.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Continuous Urine Dribbling: The hallmark symptom of an ectopic ureter, particularly in females, is constant urinary dribbling or incontinence despite normal voiding. This is because the ureter drains urine directly into a location outside the bladder, where it cannot be stored.
  • Normal Voiding: The girl still voids normally because she likely has a second, normally positioned ureter that drains into the bladder, allowing for regular voiding alongside the continuous leakage from the ectopic ureter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter as it enters the bladder, which can cause obstruction and lead to urinary symptoms. However, it does not typically cause continuous dribbling.

 

Option C. Congenital megaureter: This refers to an abnormal dilation of the ureter, usually associated with some degree of obstruction or reflux, but it does not typically present with continuous dribbling of urine.

 

Option D. Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR): VUR is the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and possibly the kidneys. It can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections and renal damage but does not typically cause continuous dribbling of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An ectopic ureter should be suspected in a young female with continuous dribbling of urine since birth, despite normal voiding, due to the abnormal insertion of the ureter outside the bladder.
