questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-Arginine

 

Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized from L-arginine through the action of enzymes known as nitric oxide synthases (NOS). There are different forms of NOS enzymes, including endothelial NOS (eNOS) and neuronal NOS (nNOS), which are involved in the production of NO in various tissues and cells. L-arginine serves as the precursor for NO synthesis in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L-Citrulline: While L-citrulline is related to the nitric oxide pathway, it is not the direct precursor for NO synthesis. Instead, L-citrulline can be converted back into L-arginine in the body, and then L-arginine is used for NO production. This makes L-citrulline indirectly involved in the regulation of NO levels.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine is not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It is an amino acid with its own metabolic functions in the body but is not a precursor for NO.

 

Option D. Lysine: Lysine is also not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It is an essential amino acid with its own roles in protein synthesis and metabolism but is not part of the NO synthesis pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by enzyme NOS (Nitric oxide synthase) in the endothelial cells.

 

 

NO is also called as Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor (EDRF). It causes vasodilatation and acts through the formation of secondary messenger cGMP.

 

NOS (multienzyme complex)

 

  • There are three isoforms of NOS 
    1. iNOS- inducible
    2. nNOS - neuronal
    3. eNOS- endothelial

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Kawasaki disease?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purulent conjunctivitis


Kawasaki disease is a medium vessel vasculitis that typically affects children and involves several characteristic features. The mnemonic "REEMA" helps remember these features:

 

  • R for Rash: Patients with Kawasaki disease often have a polymorphous rash.
  • E for Edema: Edema of the hands and feet is common in Kawasaki disease.
  • E for Eyes: Patients have non-purulent conjunctivitis, which is a hallmark of the disease.
  • M for Mucosal involvement: Mucosal changes include a strawberry tongue and cracked lips.
  • A for Adenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is a typical feature.
  • Patients also exhibit prolonged fever lasting more than five days.
  • Thrombocytosis (increased platelet count) is another feature of Kawasaki disease during the subacute phase.

 

Purulent conjunctivitis, which involves a discharge of pus, is not a feature of Kawasaki disease. Instead, patients typically have non-purulent conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Non-purulent conjunctivitis is a feature of Kawasaki disease, whereas purulent conjunctivitis is not.

questions.text: Which of the following opioids is an antagonist at ‘µ’ and a complete agonist at ‘k’ receptors? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pentazocine

 

Pentazocine is an opioid agonist-antagonist agent, which acts as a full agonist at the Kappa receptors but as a partial agonist or antagonist at the mu receptors. It is used as an analgesic, but contraindicated in myocardial infarction due to its potential to increase heart rate and blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at mu (μ) receptors and an antagonist at kappa (κ) receptors. It is used for pain management and in the treatment of opioid dependence.

 

Option C. Tramadol: Tramadol is a weak agonist at mu (μ) receptors and also inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. It does not have significant kappa (κ) receptor activity.

 

Option D. Fentanyl: Fentanyl is a potent full agonist at mu (μ) receptors with no significant activity at kappa (κ) receptors. It is used for severe pain management, particularly in surgical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pentazocine is an opioid that acts as an antagonist at mu (μ) receptors and a full agonist at kappa (κ) receptors. This unique profile allows it to serve as an analgesic with a potentially lower risk of certain side effects, although it is contraindicated in myocardial infarction.

choices.text: 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 5 years
600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years
1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years
1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for life

questions.text: An 11-year-old child who weighs 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis presents to you with fever and arthralgia. There is no past history of rheumatic heart disease or features of carditis or valvular disease. How often is benzathine penicillin recommended for prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years

 

For secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever, especially in patients without carditis or valvulitis, the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines recommend administering benzathine penicillin G for either 5 years or until the patient is 21 years old, whichever is longer. Given that the child in this case is 11 years old, prophylaxis should continue until the child turns 21, resulting in a total duration of 10 years.

 

The dosage of benzathine penicillin G depends on the patient's weight:

 

  • For children weighing less than 27 kg, the dose is 600,000 IU.
  • For children weighing 27 kg or more, the dose is 1,200,000 IU.

 

Since the child weighs 26 kg, the appropriate dose is 600,000 IU. In high-risk areas such as India, the injection is administered every 3 weeks to ensure effective prophylaxis against recurrent streptococcal infections that could lead to rheumatic fever.

 

Note - Treatment duration options for a patient with valvulitis:

 

  • Standard Treatment Duration: Patients can be treated for a total duration of 10 years or until they reach the age of 40, whichever comes later. This approach is likely considered for cases where the valve damage is not extensively severe or life-threatening.
  • Severe Valve Damage: If there is severe damage to the valves, such as cases leading to or involving heart failure, lifelong therapy is recommended. This could include ongoing medication to manage the condition and potentially surgical interventions like valve replacement to address the mechanical deficits caused by the damage.

 

Note –

  • First-Line Therapy:
    • Injectable Penicillin: Typically administered once every 3 to 4 weeks.
    • Oral Alternative or if the patient prefers not to receive injections, Penicillin V can be used orally at a dose of 250 mg BD.
  • Second-Line Therapy (For patients with Penicillin Allergy): Sulfadiazine
  • Third-Line Therapy (For patients with both Penicillin and Sulfa Allergies): Macrolides (Either erythromycin or azithromycin, with erythromycin typically prescribed at 250 mg BD)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 5 years: This option would be correct if the duration were 5 years, but since the patient must receive prophylaxis until age 21, this is insufficient.

 

Option C. 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years: This dosage is for children weighing 27 kg or more. Since the child in this case weighs 26 kg, this dose is too high.

 

Option D. 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for life: Lifelong prophylaxis with this dosage is only indicated in patients with severe valvular damage, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an 11-year-old child weighing 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis and no carditis or valvulitis, benzathine penicillin G prophylaxis should be administered at a dose of 600,000 IU every 3 weeks for a duration of 10 years (until the child turns 21 years old).

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

 

Explanation

 

  • In the given case scenario, vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management.
  • This is also called as Ward Mayo repair
  • This is recommended to patients who satisfy the following criteria:
    • >40 years of age
    • Have completed their families
    • Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fothergill repair: This is also known as Manchester repair and involves conserving the uterus. In this procedure, cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments is done. It is done in young women who have completed their families with utero-vaginal prolapse.

 

Option B. Sling operation: This is preferred in women who are young, nulliparous (yet to have children/ complete their families) with prolapse

 

Option D. Shirodkar procedure: This is a modification of Manchester/ Fothergill surgery and does not include cervical amputation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair (Ward Mayo repair) is the preferred management for older women (>40 years) with third degree uterine prolapse who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

 

Ref: Page 221, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.text: In a case of blunt abdominal trauma, a 30-year-old male patient presents with pelvic fracture, minimal urine output on catheterization, and no blood at the meatus. The radiological image shows extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity. What is the preferred next step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparotomy

 

The pattern of contrast extravasation in the given image suggests intraperitoneal bladder rupture, which is caused by a blow or fall on the distended bladder. The preferred next step of management, in this case, is laparotomy for repair and bladder drainage (suprapubic and urethral catheter). Hence, the correct option is C) Laparotomy. Laparoscopic approaches are also now being used.

 

Laparotomy is the preferred next step in management when a patient presents with of extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity (intra-peritoneal rupture), as it may lead to chemical peritonitis. This suggests a significant bladder injury, and a laparotomy is necessary to assess the extent of the injury and provide appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy may be considered in cases of pelvic fracture and suspected urethral rupture. Absence of blood at urethral meatus rules out urethral rupture.

 

Option B. Perurethral catheterization: Perurethral catheterization may not be the best choice in this situation. It is preferred in extra-peritoneal ruptures.

 

Option D. Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy: Pelvic packing and percutaneous nephrostomy may be considered in certain cases of pelvic trauma but are not the primary management options when there is evidence of intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

questions.text: What is the reason behind Senile Atrophy? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced blood supply

 

Senile atrophy is seen when there is a reduced blood supply to a tissue.

 

  • Atrophy is decrease in cell size and/or number due to decreased demand or functional loss.
  • 2 pathways responsible for it: Ubiquitin Pathway (via Proteasomes) and Autophagy (Defense mechanism).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Denervation: Atrophy due to loss of nerve supply is known as denervation atrophy, commonly seen in conditions like poliomyelitis.

 

Option B. Decreased nutrition: This refers to atrophy due to inadequate nutrient supply, leading to cachexia.

 

Option C. Decreased workload: This refers to disuse atrophy, where tissues reduce in size due to inactivity, such as muscle wasting in immobilized limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Senile atrophy is primarily due to reduced blood supply, leading to tissue shrinkage and loss of function with aging.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis. She is prescribed metronidazole as part of her treatment plan. Which of the following should she avoid consuming while on this medication? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol

 

  • Patients taking metronidazole are advised to avoid alcohol consumption. Metronidazole and alcohol can interact to cause a disulfiram-like reaction, leading to symptoms such as flushing, nausea, vomiting, palpitations, and even more severe reactions in some cases. This interaction can occur not only with oral alcohol consumption but also with alcohol contained in mouthwashes and certain medications.
  • Disulfiram is an aversive drug, that inhibits the aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body, which can lead to symptoms like throbbing headache, flushing, chest tightness, visual disturbances, nausea etc. Hence these symptoms prevent the patient from taking alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grapefruit juice: There is no known significant interaction between grapefruit juice and metronidazole.

 

Option C. Benzodiazepine: While caution may be advised when combining any medications that can have CNS effects, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between benzodiazepines and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Option D. SSRI: Similar to benzodiazepines, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between SSRIs and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs that can cause disulfiram like reaction include:

 

Cyclic:  Cefoperazone, Chlorpropamide

 

G:         Grieseofulvin

 

M:        Metronidazole

 

P:         Procarbazine

choices.text: Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE
Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following is true about intracellular regulation of iron in the above condition? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IP to IRE

 

In iron deficiency anaemia, ferritin translation is decreased by binding iron regulatory protein to iron response elements.

 

Dietary iron is carried in the blood by transferrin and enters cells via endocytosis, mediated by the transferrin receptor. Excess iron is stored by binding to ferritin. The levels of transferrin, transferrin receptor (TfR), and ferritin are therefore crucial to cellular iron homeostasis.

 

The iron regulatory proteins (IRPs) are two cytoplasmic RNA-binding proteins that control iron metabolism which bind to iron response elements (IRE) which are mRNA regions consisting of ferritin and transferrin receptor.

 

When the IRPs bind to the 5' untranslated IRE sequence in the ferritin mRNA, ferritin translation is blocked resulting in decreased ferritin.

 

When IPs are bound to the 3' end of the untranslated IRE sequence, there is increase in transferrin receptor per mRNA molecule due to reduced proteolysis of Tf receptor.

 

In iron-deficiency, iron stores (ferritin) is reduced and iron uptake (through transferrin receptor) is increased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE: This is incorrect because binding of IRP to IRE inhibits ferritin translation.

 

Option C. Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE: This is incorrect. IRP binding to IRE at the 3' untranslated region of transferrin receptor mRNA actually increases the stability and translation of transferrin receptor mRNA, increasing iron uptake.

 

Option D. Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE: This is incorrect as described above; binding of IRP to IRE increases transferrin receptor 1 translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron deficiency anemia, ferritin translation is decreased due to the binding of IRP to IRE in the ferritin mRNA, reducing iron storage and making more iron available for use.

choices.text: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.text: Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defect in DNA helicase

 

Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to a defect in DNA helicase.

 

This rare genetic disorder is characterized by premature aging, with patients typically experiencing symptoms associated with aging at an accelerated rate. The defective gene product in Werner syndrome is a DNA helicase, a protein that plays a key role in DNA replication and repair by unwinding the double helix structure of DNA.

 

 

A defect in this enzyme leads to the rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage, which can mimic the cellular aging process. This chromosomal damage is believed to contribute to the Clinical features of Werner syndrome, such as premature graying and hair loss, thinning and wrinkling of the skin and hyperpigmentation, cataracts, osteoporosis, Short Stature, Metabolic Abnormalities and an increased risk of cancer.

 

The diagnosis of Werner syndrome is typically based on clinical features, family history, and genetic testing. There is no cure for Werner syndrome, and treatment is primarily supportive and focused on managing symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased telomerase activity: Increased telomerase activity typically prevents telomere shortening, which is not associated with the premature aging seen in Werner syndrome.

 

Option C. Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity: Decreased telomerase activity leads to shortened telomeres, not an increase in length. However, telomere lengthening is not a feature of Werner syndrome.

 

Option D. Reduced free radicals: Reduced free radicals would theoretically reduce oxidative damage and potentially slow aging. This is not related to the premature aging observed in Werner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Premature aging in Werner syndrome is primarily due to a defect in DNA helicase, leading to rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage and the manifestation of aging-related symptoms at an accelerated rate.

choices.text: Used syringe with needle
Paper wrapper from gloves

questions.text: A healthcare worker is cleaning up after a procedure involving a blood draw. She has several items to dispose of, as mentioned below. According to proper biomedical waste management guidelines, which of the following should be disposed of in the red bin?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Used gloves

 

Explanation:

 

The red bin is designated for contaminated recyclable waste, such as used gloves, tubing, and plastic items that have been exposed to bodily fluids. The used gloves in this case should be disposed of in the red bin, as they have been in contact with a patient and are considered contaminated medical waste.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Used syringe with needle: This belongs in a sharps bin, designed for the safe disposal of needles, scalpels, and other sharp items to prevent injury and infection.

 

Option B) Blood-soiled gauze: Should be disposed of in the yellow bin, which is used for biomedical waste, such as items contaminated with blood or bodily fluids. These require disinfection or incineration.

 

Option D) Paper wrapper from gloves: Should be placed in the black bin, which is for non-infectious general waste, like paper wrappers or food waste.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of type 2 diabetes is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. SGLT2 inhibitors work by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine. This mechanism of action results in a higher concentration of glucose in the urinary tract, which can promote bacterial growth and lead to an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: This drug is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity but is not associated with an increased risk of UTIs. Instead, it can cause side effects such as fluid retention, weight gain, and an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: This is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor that increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels in the bloodstream. It is associated with risks such as pancreatitis and gastrointestinal disturbances but not with an increased risk of UTIs.

 

Option D. Metformin: This is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. Common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., diarrhea) and vitamin B12 deficiency, but it does not increase the risk of UTIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This highlights the importance of monitoring for UTIs in patients prescribed this medication.

choices.text: Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

questions.text: Pregnant women with which of the following is called systemic hypertension? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

 

Explanation:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is classified as chronic hypertension if it is diagnosed in the first trimester or if hypertension persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum. Hypertension present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation also qualifies as chronic hypertension. This is distinct from gestational hypertension, which develops after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman.

 

  • Chronic Hypertension: Defined as blood pressure of ≥ 140/90 mm Hg that was present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic retinopathy: This condition is a complication of diabetes affecting the eyes, not a direct indicator of systemic hypertension.

 

Option C. Diabetic nephropathy: This is a complication of diabetes that affects the kidneys and can be associated with hypertension, but it is not specific to the definition of systemic hypertension in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Episode of seizure: Seizures in the context of pregnancy are associated with eclampsia, a severe form of preeclampsia, but do not directly define systemic hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is diagnosed if high blood pressure is present before pregnancy, is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 39 year G2P1 presents at 18 weeks 5 days for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm. Despite being counselled that there is no clear proven benefit for the same; the patient insisted on a cervical cerclage. Which of the following is a complete contra-indication to cerclage? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruptured membranes

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ruptured Membranes:
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.

 

Absolute Contraindications to Cervical Cerclage

 

  • Active labor
  • Clinical signs of chorioamnionitis
  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • Fetal demise (IUFD)
  • Major fetal anomalies incompatible with life
  • Significant vaginal bleeding due to placental abruption
  • ruptured membranes 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test: A positive fetal fibronectin test indicates an increased risk of preterm labor but is not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. This test measures the presence of fetal fibronectin, a protein that acts as a "glue" during pregnancy, keeping the amniotic sac attached to the lining of the uterus.

 

Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina: While bulging membranes present a high-risk situation, they are not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. In some cases, cerclage can still be performed with careful management.

 

Option D. Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is not a contraindication to cerclage. While it may increase the overall risk profile of the pregnancy, it does not specifically contraindicate the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cervical cerclage due to the increased risk of infection and complications.

 

Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reef knot

 

The image shows a reef knot, also called as square knot:

  • It is the most Basic Surgical Knot
  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

 

Other Surgical knots

 

Granny Knot

  • Two Throws in the Same Direction
  • Not as Strong as Square Knot – Can Slip

 

 

 

 

Option C: Surgeon’s Knot

  • Initial Throw is Pulled Through Twice
  • Second Throw in Opposite Direction
  • More Stable than a Square Knot

 

 

Option A: Surgical Slip Knot (Double Half-Hitch)

  • Keeping Tension on One End the Initial Knot is Thrown Twice in the Same Direction and then Pulled Tight
    • Essentially a “Purposeful” Granny Knot
  • Following Throws in Opposite Directions to Lock
  • Allows Initial Tightening of the Knot to Ensure Tightness

 

Other Options :

 

 

 

Educational Objective: The reef knot has

 

  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

questions.text: Drug resistance is most commonly seen with which of the following infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

  • Gonorrhea is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is notorious for developing resistance to multiple classes of antibiotics, including penicillins, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, and most recently, some strains have shown reduced susceptibility to cephalosporins and azithromycin. Drug-resistant gonorrhea is a significant public health challenge, and the CDC recommends dual therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin to address this issue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. While there have been cases of antibiotic resistance, it is not as prevalent or significant as in gonorrhea.

 

Option B. Donovanosis: Donovanosis (granuloma inguinale) is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It is relatively rare, and drug resistance has not been a major issue in its treatment.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. While there are concerns about resistance to some antibiotics, such as macrolides, penicillin remains highly effective, and resistance is not as significant a problem as in gonorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, gonorrhea is the infection most commonly associated with drug resistance, making it a critical concern in the treatment of STIs.

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test

 

The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

 

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

 

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

 

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/uL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test): This test is highly sensitive for detecting the presence of antibodies to Treponema pallidum and is used to confirm a syphilis infection but is not specific for neurosyphilis as it can be positive due to past or present infection anywhere in the body.

 

Option C. RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin test): Similar to VDRL, used as a screening test for syphilis based on the detection of non-treponemal antibodies indicative of an active infection, but not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization test): This is an older, highly specific test that is not commonly used today.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CSF-VDRL test, despite its low sensitivity, remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of neurosyphilis due to its high specificity when positive. It is crucial in the diagnostic process for patients with suspected syphilis infection of the central nervous system, helping guide appropriate treatment and management.
